metadata.title: Pickering Emulsion Gels Based on Halloysite Nanotubes and Ionic Biopolymers: Properties and Cleaning Action on Marble Surface

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: halloysite, Pickering emulsion, pectin, chitosan, cultural heritage, cleaning
■ INTRODUCTION Emulsions are widely used in cleaning protocols, and they are particularly attractive in the conservation of cultural heritage. Oil-in-water emulsions present as their main advantage the possibility to obtain a controlled cleaning, minimizing the use of organic solvents for the removal of hydrophobic coherent layers onto a surface. The use of emulsions combines the detergency and surface active properties of the surfactant with the synergistic solving action of the organic solvent. Typically, microemulsions are engineered and preferred to emulsions due to their thermodynamic stability. The first successful use of a microemulsion in art conservation was reported for the frescoes by Masaccio and Masolino (Brancacci Chapel in Florence, Italy).1 In recent years, several formulations were proposed, with the aim of solving specific cleaning issues, the majority of which are selective and controlled removal of undesired materials and the use of sustainable products as well as reduction of the risk of surfactant/cleaning agents residues on the artwork surface.2−5 Particular attention has been devoted to the uncontrolled spreading and penetration of the
formulations that can lead to unpredictable damage effects. To overcome these issues, alternatives for emulsion stabilizers and gel-forming strategies should be considered. In this regard, a Pickering emulsion could represent a prospective approach. Pickering emulsions are stabilized with solid particles instead of surfactants, and they exhibit high stability due to their opposition to Oswald ripening and coalescence phenomena.6 Among solid inexpensive and sustainable stabilizers, clay minerals with a variable hollow tubular morphology are very promising. Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) have been so efficient in oil-in-water emulsion stabilization that they have been proposed for oil remediation technology.7,8 In this respect, HNTs represent a great advantage to be easily dispersed in water media without time-consuming exfoliation procedures needed for other platy clays. Halloysite nanotubes can be used in water purification,9−11 catalysis,12−15 drug

delivery,16−24 packaging,25−28 and conservation of cultural heritage as consolidant agents29,30 due to their versatile surface chemistry and interesting colloidal properties.31−36 Very recently, the combination of HNTs with anionic surfactants generated inorganic micelles with solubilization ability toward hydrophobic payloads.10,37,38 Additionally, HNTs are not toxic to cells, yeast, and multicellular organisms.17,39−43 HNTs are quite polydisperse in size, with characteristic sizes largely dependent on the deposit. Their typical length is ca. 1 μm, while the external diameter and the lumen range between 50 and 80 nm and between 10 and 15 nm, respectively.44−47 Halloysite possesses peculiar interface properties, as the inner and outer surfaces are oppositely charged (positive and negative, respectively). The overall charge of an HNT is negative, as demonstrated by its ζ potential value (−20.1 mV), which makes the nanotubes partially stable in water. In this regard, literature has evidenced that the addition of ionic and nonionic polymers can enhance the HNT aqueous colloidal stability as a consequence of electrostatic and steric mechanisms, respectively.48
With regard to the thickener additives to increase the viscosity of the emulsion, different biopolymers are commonly used in conservation such as cellulose ethers and other polysaccharides (agar, xanthan gum). These rigid gels allow minimizing the amount of residues left after the application.49
Among biopolymers, chitosan and pectin could represent efficient alternatives as thickener additives for conservation issues. Both ionic polymers show interesting colloidal behavior, forming hydrogels under specific conditions. Chitosan solution becomes highly viscous at basic pH, while pectin forms gels in the presence of calcium dications. In addition, these biopolyelectrolytes were successful in controlling the HNTs aqueous colloidal stability as a consequence of selective electrostatic interactions with the inner/outer surfaces of halloysite.48 Pectin and chitosan possess an ion exchange capability that can be helpful for surface cleaning. On the basis of these considerations, these ionic biopolymers are promising in the context of more recent developments in gels and microemulsions, such as nanostructured fluids and composite gel systems.50
Here, we propose a new strategy for designing a Pickering emulsion based on halloysite nanotubes and exploring chitosan and pectin as thickener additives (Scheme 1). These two
biopolymers represent very abundant and low-cost materials, and their use is in agreement with the idea of a circular economy, as they are a waste of the food industry. Nanocomposite films of halloysite nanotubes in combination with pectin and chitosan have been considered promising for sustainable packaging applications and tissue engineering.19,51−54 Their use as thickeners can have an influence on
the stabilization/destabilization and detergency ability of the Pickering emulsion.
■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Materials. Citrus pectin (degree of methyl esterification 24%, Mw = 30−100 kg mol−1, impurity ≤10%), n-decane (≥99%), Ba(OH)2 (∼95%), NaOH (≥98%), chitosan (75−85% deacetylated, Mw = 50− 190 kg mol−1), glacial acetic acid (≥99%), and halloysite (HNT) were obtained from Sigma. Electron and atomic force micrographs of HNT samples are presented in Figure 1, while Table 1 collects the main
properties of halloysite in terms of molar mass per cell unit, density, specific surface area, and ζ potential. All of the products were used without further purification. Water from reverse osmosis with a specific resistivity greater than 1 MΩ cm was used.
Pickering Emulsion Preparation. HNTs were dispersed in water at 1.0%; after ultrasonication (10 min), the dispersion was stirred overnight. n-Decane was added to the dispersion at a oil to water ratio of 1:3. An emulsion was obtained by vortex mixing for 2 min. The obtained emulsion was creamy white and stable for more than 1 month at room temperature.
Pectin and Chitosan Gel Preparation. Pectin was dissolved in water (5 wt %) with magnetic stirring at 70 °C. The solution was left to equilibrate with magnetic stirring overnight at room temperature. Then, appropriate amounts of HNTs and n-decane were added to the pectin solution following the protocol described for the Pickering emulsion preparation. The gel phase was obtained by adding a Ba(OH)2 saturated solution (ca. 47 g dm
−3) with magnetic stirring. The final barium hydroxide concentration in the gel was 0.4 wt %, and the gel pH was 8.2.
Chitosan was dissolved at 2 wt % in acetic acid (1 wt %) aqueous solution with magnetic stirring at room temperature. The solution was magnetically stirred overnight at room temperature. A Pickering emulsion was prepared on the basis of the previously described protocol by adding appropriate amounts of HNTs and n-decane to the chitosan solution. The gel phase was obtained by adding dropwise an Na(OH) solution (1.5 M) with magnetic stirring. The final sodium hydroxide concentration in the gel was ca. 0.3 M, and the gel pH was 12.1.
Cleaning Tests. A Pickering emulsion in gel was applied onto the solid surface (marble with wax layer or funeral monument of Placido Caruso). A layer of ca. 0.5 cm was kept for a certain time before its removal by means of a cotton swab. Finally, a mild rinsing with water on a cotton swab was performed to remove the residuals.

Methods. A Carl Zeiss Libra transmission electron microscope (TEM) instrument was used to capture TEM images of halloysite nanotubes. A droplet of an aqueous halloysite suspension was placed onto a Formvar-coated copper grid (Agar) and left to evaporate. The samples were imaged at 120 V accelerating voltage. Fluorescence spectra of the pectin-based gel and marble surface were recorded using a Fluoromax 4 (Jobin-Yvon) spectrofluorometer (30° angle geometry). The excitation wavelength was fixed at 313 nm, while the emission spectra were registered from 330 to 600 nm. Water contact angle measurements were performed with an apparatus equipped with a CCD camera with high resolution (OCA 20, Data Physics Instruments). SCA 20 software (Data Physics Instruments) was used for data analysis. The water contact angle just after the deposition (θi) was measured by placing a 10.0 ± 0.5 μL droplet onto the solid surface. The HNTs powder was pressed in a Carver laboratory press at room temperature under 1500 psi for 10 min to obtain a tablet. Each measurement was repeated at least three times, and the average values are reported. The color parameter changes of the marble surface upon cleaning were followed by an image analysis according to the literature,55 acquiring by a flatbed digital scanner images as RGB files at a spatial resolution of 1200 dpi and converting the image to laboratory coordinates by means of ImageJ software. The color change expressed as ΔE parameter was calculated as the average value in an area of ca. 1 cm × 1 cm. The “cleaned” marble surface was defined for water contact angle and color change experiments by considering the surface after polishing with sandpaper. The surface tension experiments were carried out by using a programmable tensiometer (KSV Sigma 70) equipped with a Wilhelmy plate at 25.0 ± 0.1 °C. The platinum plate was lowered to the surface of the solution, and the downward force to the plate was measured. Surface tension was obtained as the force divided by the perimeter of the plate. The optical micrographs were taken with an Optika polarizing microscope at room temperature, and the size distribution was obtained by using ImageJ software.56 The pH of the biopolymer gels was detemined by using a PCD650 pH meter (Eutech Instruments, Landsmeer). Confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) images were taken using a LSM 780 instrument (Carl Zeiss). The emulsion was first vortexed for 20 s, and then a droplet (7 μL) of the emulsion was placed onto a glass slide and sandwiched by a glass coverslip. The fluorescence was excited by using a 488 nm argon laser; images were
processed using ZEN Black software. Dark-field and corresponding fluorescence microscopy images were captured using an Olympus BX51 upright microscope equipped with 100× fluorite objective, a Cytoviva high annular aperture dark-field condenser, and DAGE CCD camera. Fluorescence in the sample was excited using an X-cite 120Q wide-field fluorescence excitation light source (Excelitas Technologies) and a Cytoviva Dual Mode Fluorescence system; the exposure time was 300 μs. Images were captured using Exponent 7 software (Dage-MTI). Reflected light spectra were recorded in the range 400−1000 nm with a 2.0 nm spectral resolution using a Specim spectrometer and Pixelfly USB (PCO) CCD camera. ENVI 4.8 software was used to process the spectra obtained. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were obtained using a Dimension Icon instrument (Bruker) equipped with ScanAsyst-Air (Bruker) probes (nominal length 115 μm, tip radius 2 nm, spring constant 0.4 N m−1) (Bruker). AFM raw data obtained were processed using Nanoscope Analysis software v 1.7 (Bruker).
■ RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Characterization of Pickering Emulsion. The Pickering emulsions in gel were imaged by an optical microscope. The oil/HNTs/water Pickering emulsion clearly showed the presence of oil droplets having a radius ranging between 20 and 40 μm (Figure 2). This value is in agreement with that reported for a similar system in the literature.7 Interestingly, the presence of a biopolymer (both chitosan and pectin) and the formation of a gel phase affected both the stability and the distribution of the oil droplets in the Pickering emulsions. As shown in Figure 2, a Pickering emulsion in chitosan gel possesses a clear phase separation, although the oil droplets are still present. In contrast, oil droplets are homogeneously dispersed in the pectin gel phase. In comparison to oil/HNTs/ water Pickering emulsions, the droplet size distribution is shifted toward a smaller value in the presence of pectin gel. Therefore, pectin simultaneously acts as gelling agent and emulsion stabilizer. The confocal imaging confirms the optical observations. It should be noted that the detected fluorescence signal is due to pectin autofluorescence, and it shows an
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00487 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 3169−3176
3171
accumulation of the biopolymer close to the droplet (Figure 3). On the basis of the collected images, one cannot exclude
that pectin is also penetrating the droplets. Dark-field images and hyperspectral data analysis provided a deeper understanding of the location of the halloysite nanotubes within the emulsion system. Comparing correlative dark-field and fluorescence microscopy images of the emulsion droplets in water, one can see the intense light scattering originating from halloysite covering the pectin gels (Figure 3a,b). The reflected light spectra obtained from the droplets is reminiscent of those for pure HNTs, and the hyperspectral images indicate the interfacial accumulation of nanotubes. In addition, CLSM images were also taken to confirm the morphology and size distribution of the emulsion droplets (Figure 3). Atomic force microscopy in nanomechanical PeakForce Tapping mode was applied to investigate the distribution of halloysite nanotubes within the pectin gels (Figure 4). The combination of surface topography and nonspecific adhesion force maps obtained using PeakForce Tapping nanomechanical AFM demonstrates that the individual nanotubes are distributed diffusely, some being embedded into the pectin matrix, while the others reside on the top of the pectin layer, as confirmed by nonspecific adhesion measurements. Individual halloysite nanotubes appear on AFM images as rodlike particles with sizes similar to those obtained for intact nanotubes (Figure 1b), although the embedding within pectin gel layers slightly affects the shape of the nanotubes. Interestingly, pectin areas exhibited a much higher (ca. 25−27 nN) nonspecific adhesion toward the AFM probe tip than surface-exposed HNTs (5−12 nN). AFM imaging of the dried emulsion droplets does not help to elucidate the intrinsic structure of the emulsion; however, this does help in investigating the distribution of nanotubes within the pectin gel and studying the uniformity of adhesive properties of the composite material. A deeper investigation into the stability of the Pickering emulsion can be achieved by studying the interfacial activity of
clay nanotubes in aqueous media. The free energy change (ΔGd) when the nanotube is detached from the oil−water interface and submerged into the aqueous phase is given by7

are strongly bonded at the interface since the detaching energy is much larger than the thermal energy. For an n-dodecane/ HNTs/water Pickering emulsion, Owoseni et al.7 reported a detaching energy value equal to (3.45 × 104)kT, which is consistent with our result (Table 2). It is clearly detected that both biopolymers enhance the HNTs affinity toward the oil− water interface, as evidenced by the ΔGd results. This effect is stronger for pectin addition, which induced a ΔGd increase greater than 1 order of magnitude with respect to that of the ndecane/HNTs/water system. It should be noted that the sizes of HNTs can be affected by stacking or aggregation at the oil− water interface, leading to network formation. As reported in the literature,7 an increase in the energy of attachment at the oil−water interface is expected due to capillary interactions in linked end-to-end HNTs. The stabilizing effect of pectin is consistent with its accumulation at the oil−water interface evidenced by confocal imaging. It is reported in the literature48 that the anionic pectin enhances the colloidal stability of a halloysite aqueous dispersion due to the increase in the net negative charge of nanotubes as a consequence of the neutralization of the HNT positive inner surface. In contrast, the cation chitosan interacts with the halloysite outer surface, speeding up the nanoclay sedimentation in aqueous medium. On the basis of the colloidal stability characteristics of biopolymer/HNTs systems, detaching energy data, and morphological observations, we can conclude that pectin is the better biopolymer to prepare a stable emulsion. Interestingly, the addition of dications can allow an increase in the viscosity of the Pickering emulsion formed in pectin gel. Cleaning of Marble Surface. We carried out a test on the ability of a Pickering emulsion in pectin gel to remove wax from a marble surface. A thin layer of ca. 100 μm of beeswax was deposited on marble samples. After this treatment the surface color appeared altered, and it turned from white to brownish. The choice of wax has a double purpose: (i) it can be considered as a model system for a hydrophobic layer and (ii) it was used as a protective layer for marble artifacts in the past and currently its removal is the first step for a cleaning protocol in conservation of cultural heritage.58,59 In this respect, wet cleaning represents an alternative protocol to other physical methods such as laser ablation.60 The efficacy of the wax removal from a marble surface was estimated by monitoring both the water contact angle and the colorimeter parameters of the surface as a function of gel application time. Figure 6 shows the macroscopic cleaning action of the gel application on the marble surface. With regard to colorimeter parameters, it is typically accepted that ΔE < 2.3 indicates undistinguished colors for human eyes.61 As reported in Figure 7, the pectin-based gel is more efficient than chitosan in wax removal. This result is likely related to the structural characteristics of the Pickering emulsions, which present phase separation and a uniformity in chitosan and pectin gels, respectively. Water contact angle data are sensitive to the cleaning process, and they show that the marble surface is free of hydrophobic substances after ca. 50 min of gel application time (Figure 8). Going further, we decided to monitor the presence of pectin residuals onto the marble surface after the cleaning procedure. To this aim fluorescence spectra were collected before and after surface rinsing with water and a cotton swab. The results indicated that pectin residuals are below the detection limit (0.8 mg cm−2, calculated as 3 times larger than the noise signal) if a proper water rinsing is performed after gel application (Figure 9).
Finally, the Pickering emulsion in pectin gel was tested in a real artwork. The cherubs of the funeral monument of Placido Caruso from St. Joseph’s Chapel in Polizzi Generosa (Italy)
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00487 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. 2019, 2, 3169−3176
3173
was selected; although a very little information about the nature of the coating was available, the surface appeared far from the typical white of marble likely due to a coherent layer of dust. Moreover, the hydrophobic nature of the deposit was proved by the low and inefficient cleaning action of water applied with a cotton swab. Thus, cleaning was carried out by means of the Pickering emulsion in pectin gel phase. The optical photos before and after the treatment (Figure 10) show
the promising results in terms of whitening and controlled cleaning of the surface after 10 min contact time. Concerning the mechanism of the cleaning process, it has been reported that surfactants remove organic matter such as wax from a surface, through roll-up, emulsification, and solubilization steps. The presence of an organic solvent in the cleaning system improves the solubilization of the hydrophobic material, dispersing it into the micelles.5,50 In our case, pectin can play the role of a gentle surfactant while the oil droplets represent the solubilization sites for the hydrophobic material.
■ CONCLUSIONS Pickering emulsion gels were successfully fabricated by the combination of halloysite nanotubes and biopolyelectrolytes (pectin and chitosan). We observed that the adsorption of the nanotubes at the water−oil interface is strongly favored from a thermodynamic point of view, and it provides a steric barrier against drop coalescence. The synergistic stabilization of emulsions was evidenced by halloysite and biopolymers (chitosan or pectin). Pectin allowed us to obtain a stable and uniform gel from the Pickering emulsion, and the polymer/nanotubes accumulation at the oil droplet surface was imaged. The shelf life of the pectin Pickering emulsion gel was estimated as 3 months. Therefore, an oil pool dispersed in microranged droplets separated from the continuous water phase by a nanotubes/pectin layer is obtained. The system is very promising in practical applications related to controlled cleaning of stone-based artifacts. In particular, the dispersion of oil into small droplets will ensure a nonaggressive and safe cleaning agent, while the gel nature provides a well-defined area of application. In addition to the encouraging cleaning performance, the prepared formulations follow a sustainable process as all components, with the exception of the oil phase, are obtained from natural sources. The great availability at low cost of halloysite nanotubes and pectin additionally renders conversion to large-scale applications feasible. Finally, the main contribution that this work offers in the field of nanomaterials for the cleaning of artworks is the introduction of a Pickering emulsion in gel phase by using biocompatible ingredients.

metadata.abstractText: We have fabricated ecocompatible Pickering emulsions based on halloysite nanotubes and ionic biopolymers (chitosan and pectin) from renewable resources. The effect of pectin and chitosan on the Pickering emulsion was investigated by direct visualization of the oil droplets and by the thermodynamic characterization at the interface. Pectin enhances the Pickering emulsion stability, while a phase separation and nonhomogeneous gel was observed in the presence of chitosan. We have demonstrated that the Pickering emulsion in a pectin based gel phase is suitable for wax layer removal from a marble surface. A controlled cleaning is achieved by tuning the contact time between the gel and the marble surface. Due to its nonhomogeneous structure, chitosan-based gel does not show proper wax removal ability. This work opens up a new sustainable approach in preparing cleaning formulations for conservation of cultural heritage.
